Question: this loop is done three times, can it just be done once with all these blocks inside?

It cannot. Because "acl" should be set together, same to "use_backend" and "backend". The configuration sequence should be:
acl_1
acl_2

use_backend_1
use_backend_2

backend_1
backend_2.

If set them in one loop, the configuration file will be:
acl_1
use_backend_1
backend_1

acl_2
use_backend_2
backend_2

which can not be parsed by haproxy.

nova/virt/libvirt/cpu/__init__.py.message:
This can lead to inconsistencies
```
>>> from nova.virt.libvirt import cpu
>>> c = cpu.Core(2)
>>> c
Core(ident=2, _path=None)
>>> c.path
'/sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu2'
>>> c.ident=3
>>> c.path
'/sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu2'
>>>
```

So
a) if path is cheap to generate then lets always generate it based on ident
b) if path expensive to generate then hide ident to `_ident` and add a getter property for it to signal it is not meant to be changed.
c) if path is expensive and you still want to allow ident to change then create an ident setter and generate the path once in the ctor and once in the ident setter.
OK, in PS3 you opt into option a) and pushed the path down the stack. that works for me.
while it is not mandatory I would add __eq__ too to define for the next developer that the intention is that two Core equals if the ident equals regardless of path

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: -W because I haven't tested the patch yet on Nautilus
We are experiencing this issue and need to merge as soon as possible.

According to documentation (https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/configuration/block-storage/drivers/ceph-rbd-volume-driver.html), cinder should support 2 active and 2 archived releases of ceph. For master they are nautilus, octopus, pacific and quincy. For all this ceph realeses "stored" key exists in df output, so we needn't to check ceph version to change behavoir to use or not use "stored" key instead of "used_bytes".

Without this fix it isn't possible to setup limits to cinder backend with max_over_subscription_ratio and reserved_percentage configuration options. So it could lead to unintended ceph overflow and IO stop.
So, this fix even supports oldest ceph realeses and keeps compatibility if early release of ceph (without "stored" in df output ) is used.

I have some uncertainty about that the solution covers our re-schedule cases. So  I would like to see a set of functional tests that triggers re-schedule due to the violation of the late group policy checks and assert that 
* i) we still correctly re-schedule if re-schedule is needed

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Takashi, the heat documentation clear states that parameters marked as hidden should not be visible in the output of a show. As a result this patch could really be deemed a security fix since the api is effectively leaking secret information. The fact that some software is relying on the existence of this bug does not justify not fixing and backporting it. The software should behave as documented and that is what this patch addresses. Therefore I believe that we absolutely should backport this patch and any software that is relying on this information should be fixed accordingly.
This has user impact and is not very good candidate for backport. Actually we recently found this breaks TripleO which relies on environment API to obtain some secrets from stack info.

Takashi, the doc you pasted is the one i was referring to. There is no mention of hidden parameters in the actual api doc unfortunately.

Rabi, when users upgrade to Antelope they will be impacted anyway since it is now fixed there. Your point about raising as a security advisory is valid.
For new releases it's fine with the release note. Consumers will change including TripleO. Backport is ticky for API changes which is normally not allowed, unless it's a CVE.

we can fix triples so that it relies on a different mechanism but that is just an example showing how this can break external software.

we should not backport any patches with api impact to avoid such a breakage and unfortunately this is not backportable because of that point, imo

Do you mind sharing any pointer of that doc ? I was not really aware of one specifically stating the environment API should mask the hidden values. I'm aware the template doc says hidden indicates the parameter should be hidden but I've not yet found any document defining specific behavior of APIs.

https://docs.openstack.org/heat/latest/template_guide/hot_spec.html#parameters-section

I agree this smelss like a security issue, but at the same time again this has api impact. It's true relying on the old behavior is not ideal but this is what has been exposed for a long time.

Probably as the next step we can involve security advisories to evaluate how critical this can be and it's justified to change api response in stable releases for this. I don't intend to hard block this in case other cores think this is justified.
May I ask if TripleO needs to implement by another API or if our patch needs to change?

Though the change is probably fine for backport considering what should be expected when a "parameter is hidden", it's a breaking change. TripleO uses the API for extracting some password parameters from stack environment[1], though they are hidden in templates. TripleO can be changed, but, we probably need to understand the implications for other 3rd party software using it before going with backport. 

Maybe creating a CVE bug and involving OpenStack Security will bolster the case for backport. 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common/blame/master/tripleo_common/inventory.py#L735

glance/policies/base.py.message:
Instead of defining as rule:context_is_admin

why not do this?

ADMIN = 'role:admin'
ADMIN_OR_PROJECT_MEMBER = f'({ADMIN}) or ({PROJECT_MEMBER})'

because this does not make it easier to override things in the policies file.

Very concrete example - I want to limit global admin to only be 'role admin in the admin project'. How would I currently have to override that via policy files? By manually re-writing most of them.

When we define the 'adminnness' as a 'rule' that can be actually defined in the policy file, I can re-define only a single rule instead:

  context_is_admin: role:admin and is_admin_project:True
  
(given Keystone is configured to send the is_admin_project flag)

What's more, the rule is already defined (L106), it is just used only for 'is_admin:True' calculation at the moment.

keystone/api/os_oauth2.py.message: So this can only work with either credentials, or mtls, but not both at the same time? Is there a particular reason?

In the previous meeting, you mentioned that the authentication methods can be handled by auth_method [1]. However, I think auth_method lists the available authentication methods when users perform authentication with `/identity/v3/auth/tokens` with `methods` field in requests. Adding something like `oauth2_cert` to auth_method may fall into error as OAuth2.0 doesn't work as a plugin for `/identity/v3/auth/tokens` [2]. For that reason, I just changed oauth2_authn_method to ListOpt which is specific for the OAuth2.0. Is this in line with your thoughts? I didn't make test cases yet. If you agree with the above, I'll add test cases.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/420f4ff46da106b67912cecdff939f5dc0b079d0/keystone/conf/auth.py#L19-L28
[2] https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/auth/core.py#L40-L65

What happens if a user doesn't have a default_project_id? It seems that instead of getting a project scoped token you return a domain scoped token. I don't like that the type of token changes based on a user attribute, instead of the request being different. If we really want this to only work for 1 project for each user, the lack of default_project_id should cause this to fail.
Changed codes to fall when `default_project_id` is empty.

As Hiromu mentioned in a different comment, I don't think passing credential_id is required or desired here. You can distinguish whether this is a oauth2_credential token from the presence of thumbprint.
Removed credential_id among all places. In this place, `domain_id` is also removed as domain-scoped token is now out-of-scope.

It needs to be modified to:
if not client_cert and client_auth and client_auth.type == 'basic':

Cause:

Application credential ID and user ID are not the same. 
client_certificate and authorization (basic secret) exist at the same time,
client_id will be replaced with the application credential ID, causing authentication to fail.

keystone/token/token_formatters.py.message:
isn't it identical with ``user_id``?
If it is, we don't need this.

The current code does not allow the user to specify credential information, so it involves code modification if needed.
I thought it should be provided separately from the `user_id` for scalability in the future when users want to specify credentials.
However, it may not be necessary as a way to achieve the current situation.
I don't think it makes sense to have users specify a different credential_id as it has nothing to do with the certificate that they're using to authenticate. Please remove the attribute.

What does you mean by "users can use different credentials"?
In the following place, `client_id` are assigned to both `user_id` and `credential_id`. Users can't change this behavior.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystone/+/860613/6/keystone/api/os_oauth2.py#356

I still feel this argument is unnecessary.

I think `credential_id` could be `user_id` or something else. It's just that this time use `user_id`.
By separating `user_id` and `credential_id`, users can use different credentials if they have multiple credentials.
But ultimately, I think it depends on the needs of users.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Describe all the changes that went in:
* handle version specific image repository name change from k8s.gcr.io to registry.k8s.io
* Disable Pod Security Policy
Add Testcase for Fresh install ISO with k8s 1.24.4

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Please take a look at the changes and let me know your thoughts. 
PS: This is an initial draft.

When installing ISO with k8s 1.25 (but not other k8s versions), we get errors like the following when doing 'kubeadm init --ignore-preflight-errors=DirAvailable--var-lib-etcd --config=/etc/kubernetes/kubeadm.yaml.

[ERROR ImagePull]: failed to pull image registry.local:9001/k8s.gcr.io/kube-apiserver:v1.25.3: output: time="2023-01-23T14:05:04Z" level=fatal msg="pulling image: rpc error: code = Unknown desc = failed to pull and unpack image \"registry.local:9001/k8s.gcr.io/kube-apiserver:v1.25.3\": failed to resolve reference \"registry.local:9001/k8s.gcr.io/kube-apiserver:v1.25.3\": pull access denied, repository does not exist or may require authorization: server message: insufficient_scope: authorization failed"

The reason for this is the upstream change in k8s 1.25 ( Switch from k8s.gcr.io to registry.k8s.io ).  See the following references to the change in k8s 1.25 .
https://github.com/vmware-tanzu/sonobuoy/issues/1734
https://github.com/kubernetes/k8s.io/wiki/New-Registry-url-for-Kubernetes-(registry.k8s.io)

I think solution is to do the following:

* Make the image_repository a versioned config parameter, in k8s-versioned.yml, and kubeadm.yaml.j2.

* Check for other usages of k8s.gcr.io and likely change to use the new image_repository variable.

* Investigate whether we have to change all registry references for k8s.gcr.io or whether we can leave as-is, eg, we have registry overrides and do this:

* TASK [common/push-docker-images : Set registries information]
ok: [localhost] => (item={'default_url': 'k8s.gcr.io', 'replaced_url': 'admin-2.cumulus.wrs.com:30093/wrcp-staging/k8s.gcr.io'})
0 >TASK [common/push-docker-images : Log in k8s, gcr, quay, ghcr, registryk8s docker registries if credentials exist]

* Solve ansible config issue when it does the following step, "kubectl --kubeconfig=/etc/kubernetes/admin.conf apply -f /usr/share/ansible/stx-ansible/playbooks/roles/common/bringup-kubemaster/files/psp-policies.yaml", i.e., TASK [common/bringup-kubemaster : Apply pod security policy].

i.e., stderr indicates:
    resource mapping not found for name: "privileged" namespace: "" from "/usr/share/ansible/stx-ansible/playbooks/roles/common/bringup-kubemaster/files/psp-policies.yaml": no matches for kind "PodSecurityPolicy" in version "policy/v1beta1"
    ensure CRDs are installed first
    resource mapping not found for name: "restricted" namespace: "" from "/usr/share/ansible/stx-ansible/playbooks/roles/common/bringup-kubemaster/files/psp-policies.yaml": no matches for kind "PodSecurityPolicy" in version "policy/v1beta1"
    ensure CRDs are installed first
Chnage image_repository as a versioned variable

Please check the changes. I have successfully installed ISO with 1.24 with deprecated API changes. It failed when I tried with k8s 1.25. I think it is a functional issue and the issue is the same dm pod is not coming up. I cannot debug it.
Please check out the changes and let me know your thoughts
I have made the changes based on your comments, please check it out.

I think the "certificateRef" is included in the param, but "client_cert" managed separately.

Thank you for your explanation.
I understand.

Thank you for your comment.

The certificate information contained here in the "client_cert" variable is required to establish a session at the transport layer using mTLS.
On the other hand, the thumbprint information contained in the "certificateRef" is used to authenticate the user with Tacker (instead of the password to authenticate the user with Tacker).
Therefore, 'certificateRef' and 'client_cert' are managed separately.

The fix is effective only on GAD environment. So, we add wrapper function for utils.output_log() into both(*) hbsd_common.py and hbsd_rest_api.py and replace caller code from utils.output_log() to self.output_log(), in order to print storage ID when running only on GAD environment. 
(*) How to know GAD or non-GAD is different between the modules. 

Other patches for Hitachi driver use utils.output_log() without fixing because printing storage ID is meaningless on them(excluding volume-replication patch).
We will replace output_log() caller from utils.output_log() to self.output_log() in other patches, if GAD is merged before merging them.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Sorry, I must be understanding this in the wrong way. What we need is to *always* define the provider VLAN networks as centralized, right? This is why we are always setting the 'reside-on-redirect-chassis' flag to True in this case.

Why then "is not centralized"? Shouldn't be "is centralized"?
It's a good option, I agree. We can document the version of core OVN is required for this feature once it's fixed in core OVN.

Thanks for exploring this. This is very confusing indeed.

If I were to implement this perhaps I would just consider 2 out of the 3 behaviors here: The second (reside False WITHOUT mac-mappings) and the third (reside False WITH mac-mappings).

I understand the third one is currently broken but this is something we can fix at core OVN level I assume.

Regarding the first one (reside True WITHOUT mac-mappings), is there any use case for this ? It's still centralized, just like the second one. Do we really need to support this non-tunneled centralized use case ?!?!

What you think, perhaps we should refactor how we do VLAN + DVR here and be sane about the options we offer to avoid creating all this confusion.

Yes, I think the right way is not check the external flat (in the specific case where I hit this, the network was not router:external, but internal, yet a provider network. This means also that utils function is actually not really accurate. It is not checking if the network is provider, but if it is external or not (meaning if it requires a neutron router to sent the traffic out or not).

So, we need to decide, should we do:
1) update the utils function so that it checks if the network is provider, and have another function to check if it is external,
2) use the new check (physical information instead of external) for this patch, and
3) mark this with a FIXME so that this is removed once the ovn bug related to it is resolved?
I would go for the 3rd option. This is a temporary fix until OVN core is fixed. So I would keep the current code and a comment (and a release note).

This is tricky and maybe at core-ovn level. Let me try to explain my findings:
- reside-on-redirect-chassis flag to True --> means traffic is not tunneled to the controller with the gateway port, but the traffic still needs to go through the controller with the gateway port (that is what I thought was distributed, but it is indeed centralized, just avoids the tunneling and therefore the MTU issue)
- reside-on-redirect-chassis flag to False --> the traffic goes tunneled to the controller with the gateway port (this is centralized too, plus requires extra MTU reduction)
- reside-on-redirect-chassis flat to False, but ovn-chassis-mac-mappings configured --> this is the true distributed, no tunnels being used, and traffic should not go to the controller with the gateway port. However this is not working as expected and the traffic is being sent (thorough genev tunnel) to the controller

Note there is a difference between your first and second cases. Reside True without mac-mappings means the traffic is centralized through the cr-lrp, but not tunneled (therefore avoiding MTU issues), while reside false without mac-mappings means tunneled to the cr-lrp (so also centralized), meaning extra reduction on the MTU needed

Ahhh, now I get that. Please, write an article about this!! And thanks for the explanation.

We just noticed in our fork:
this will break the case if `backend_name` has been provided and the existence of a vserver in a different backend should be checked

I suggest to use
```
            backend_client = data_motion.get_client_for_backend(backend_name)
            if not backend_client.vserver_exists(vserver):
                raise exception.VserverNotFound(vserver=vserver)
```

in this case

The "vserver_exists" is called by both "if" conditions, so you could leave as it was before: a single "vserver_exists" check. Also, the new code is creating two clients, instead of one (as before), each client initialization requires some storage calls consuming bandwidth and taking time. It should be avoided, if possible.

The root cause of the reported bug is because the client method "vserver_exist: is not setting the "tunneling" and the default is True. So, it is trying to check if the vserver exists tunneling to the vserver that does not exist yet. It will fail.

However, we could call the "vserver_exists" on send_request with tunneling=False[1]. This would solve the problem directly on client layer, without creating client twice.

Except in this reported case, all callers of "vserver_exists" are not using tunneling, because even the method is requesting the tunneling, the API layer only forces the tunneling when the requester client has a vserver. All "vserver_exists" are called using the "self._client" that does not have a vserver.


[1]https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/master/manila/share/drivers/netapp/dataontap/client/client_cmode.py#L294

I'm not sure we can keep this log here for a long run as it will be misleading. There are two ways to end up here:
* 1) a new test case is added that fails to mock out some part of nova and eventually import libvirt and fails on the poison
* 2) an existing test case that is properly poisoned and mocked libvirt. But an eventlet is leaked out from the test, the test finished and removed the mock. Then the leaked eventlet wakes up while a later test case runs and because the mock was removed in when the original test finished the leaked eventlet now imports libvirt and hits the poison set up by the current test.

zuul/driver/gerrit/gerritconnection.py.message:
One initial concern I've got reading this is that we get this information via ssh or http. It looks like the ssh connection has already assumed utf8 so no real regression there, but http did not. Instead python requests is/was decoding based on http headers. Except curling this URL I don't think Gerrit is giving us the text encoding type in the headers which would cause requests to fallback to charset_normalizer.

If that encoding is not utf8 we would break here. I think the chances of that happening are low hence my +2. But wanted to call that out as it may help future debugging should this ever come up.

Also worth noting if we got back utf16 instead we'd be just as broken as with the utf8 case previously. Long winded way of saying I don't think this makes anything worse, but only solves it for utf8. As an option we might look into charset-normalizer here too?

I know this isn't related to the change, but in reviewing the change I've found this set of three attributes specialness to be a bit confusing. It isn't clear why we treat them specially other than it is apparently only useful in this one scenario?

Aliases were introduced with this change https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/799127/3/zuul/executor/server.py and in the comments to that change its indicated the type of name being a string or a list of strings is confusing and the source of errors and should be changed.

I'm not sure I fully understand what the fix is though am happy to help if it can be articulated.

It appears that https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/executor/server.py#L1908 is the clue. Basically we can give a single node a number of names. This is only true for some node connection types though.

I guess the fix here would be to add aliases as an explicit attribute to Node in addition to name. Then create Node() when defined by the config with separate arguments and similarly have the executor loop over name and aliases when appropriate. The difficulty in doing this is that nodepool would also need to be updated to understand aliases and we would need a schema version (possibly with nodepool negotiating schema versions too?). This might be easier to accomplish once Zuul and nodepool share a codebase.

Line #2401 is where you would want to set max_workers=1 to try without per-image concurrency.

Also a bunch of complexity could be removed if we revert https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/60afc0eec44f698dd95d9d6ec80dad94a4b07329 now that python2 and mistral are not required.

If this is being triggered by the tripleo_container_image_prepare ansible module, it is using the ProcessLock[1], which results in a ProcessPoolExecutor. Process based concurrency was only added to support python2 and Mistral[2] so it would be worth checking with Rabi to see if there is a requirement that ansible use it.

It might be worth trying removing the line in [1] to use the default thread based lock.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/stable/wallaby/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_container_image_prepare.py#L147
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/60afc0eec44f698dd95d9d6ec80dad94a4b07329

zuul/manager/__init__.py.message: NIT: should return False if jobs is empty to be faithful to the original. But it doesn't mean much if the bug mentioned line 984 isn't addressed

The callsite for executeJobs() does check the return value: https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/manager/__init__.py#L1622 However as has been pointed out there appears to be a long standing bug here. It seems previously we could've returned False or None both of which would prevent setting changed = True at the call site. With this change we should always return None which has the same effect.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> This doesn't seem like the right place for this.  Variables are job-specific and it doesn't seem like the pipeline is the right place to specify them. 
> 
> I could see adding a boolean on the pipeline to enable or disable reporting returned variables entirely.
> 
> Or I could see specifying what variables are reported on the job.
> 
> Can you elaborate on the use case?

Currently, when index-returned-vars is set to true, the reporter will create a document in elasticsearch containing `zuul_return`-ed data.
However, the returned data can get quite big when the pipeline contains jobs that add comment on the patchset content.
This impacts the performance of our ES cluster and we would like to be able to remove unwanted attributes from the build document (eg, filter out the `zuul` dict).

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> Maybe the es reporter should just always not report the zuul comment data?

I guess that could be an option but this would be a breaking change on the reporter. Also we might need in the future to filter some other variables depending on the pipeline.

This way makes filtering zuul_return'd variables opt-in and is more flexible.

What do you think ?

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> I think it was an error to include the zuul data in the first place (it's for zuul, it's not the actual return data).  So I'd go one step further -- we should pop the entire zuul entry from the dict before we report it.  That's what I just did for the mqtt reporter, and I think this should behave the same way.
> 
> I'd just do that and add a deprecation release note to let people know.  No one should be relying on that.

I've updated the review accordingly to your comment 👍
The main issue we have can be dealt by removing `zuul` data from the indexed document

distributedcloud/dcmanager/api/controlle.message:
May want to try the following logic (pseudo code)

if payload has admin_subnet:
    (subcloud update request involves network reconfiguration)
    ensure subcloud is unmanaged, otherwise return an error
    update subcloud deploy_status to reconfiguring-network
    make RPC cast request update_subcloud_with_network_reconfig() 
    return subcloud
else:
    (subcloud update request is either manage/unmanage or does not involve network
     configuration)
    make RPC call request update_subcloud()
    return subcloud
ensure the subcloud is online and unmanged.

openstack/image/v2/_proxy.py.message:
We don't suffix things in the proxy layer with '_list': we pluralize.

  server_list -> servers
  image_list -> images
  cache_list -> ?

This is singular, yet you call '_list'. Does this return a single resource or multiple resources? Based on [1] I suspect the former, so this should call '_get', right?

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstacksdk/+/869710/comment/4e4314ac_6f48fec1/

That's not really relevant. You use '_list' if you're returning multiple resources in generator form. If you're returning a single resource, you use '_get' (even if that single resource contains multiple resources). For example, consider images. 'images' will return a generator of images, while 'get_image' returns a single image. There's no way this will return a generator, right? 'GET /cache' returns an object, not a list of objects, yeah? If so, this should be called 'get_image_cache' and you should call '_get' here, not '_list'
We are trying to retrieve the list of images in cache, hence using _list

So you want something like:

  cached_images = resource.Body('cached_images', type=list, list_type=CachedImage)
  queued_images = resource.Body('queued_images', type=list, list_type=QueuedImage)

I think we should make the deletion failure an explicit failure to block node.destroy from occurring, so we don't orphan data.

I'm thinking this because one of the bigger complaints I've heard from long term operators is unknown/orphaned data being stored in swift.

The "new_serial" value in both cases (old and new code pieces) is exactly the same value:

Hey Arkady. This is to add support for batch processing of incrementing the serial. The problem is that in a world where we batch these serial updates, the first call to update_zone won't have the new serial until the zone is back in ACTIVE. Though the load-sharing benefit would have less effect as it would only be relevant for instances that don't have floating IPs (for which load-sharing would happen naturally). The API for managing BFD needs more thought in this spec.

Manually associating those sessions with each route or router can be tedious for an operator.

At the same time, creating too many BFD sessions could be avoided as well if the gateway device could specify a single BFD peer IP for multiple subnets: that way multiple routes could reuse the same BFD record and its settings.

We'll have a minimal way to specify the need to use BFD with default settings in this spec for now.

Follow-on work might include implementing a full BFD spec:
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/xena/bfd_support.html

This is an important difference from the previous multiple-external-gateways spec.

Bringing an analogy with the L3-agent based implementation, this is much like having multiple snat-<router-id> namespaces across multiple nodes with multiple gateway IPs present in them at the same time (compared to the typical L3HA behavior of one VIP jumping around those namespaces on failover).

There is an option of matching on a combination of a network_id and external_fixed_ips assigned after gateway ports get attached.

This will require an operator to specify the concrete IPs in the request but:

1) will be explicit
2) will not require an API change from what is proposed.

Just want to make an observation after staring enough time at the existing code base.

There is currently a design issue to overcome which can be phrased as: "how can we identify individual gateway instances?". The current API for associating a gateway with a router is network-centric, not port-centric (Neutron is responsible for creating the network:router_gateway port and an operator is not involved). This creates an issue for the extra gateways API since in this proposal the aim is to allow multiple external gateways associated with the same network_id. For example:

* When updating external gateways provided that there are multiple gateways attached to the same network an operator needs to know which ones will be updated consistently across API calls (Neutron will want to know too if we hope to have deterministic tests);
* When deleting external gateways an operator might want to be able to delete just some (not all) gateways associated with the same network_id. Moreover, we may want to specify which ones in particular. However, since there is no way to identify them besides external_gateway_info "content + order in the request body" this becomes a problem.

As there's currently no identification mechanism for "gateways" - this is a collection of state that's not just a particular port_id or a network_id. The existing design always assumes there is only one gateway and does not bother with ID-ing individual instances. With multi-homing we need some form of enumiration.

This also becomes important for the existing codebase reuse as methods like _validate_gw_info make assumptions based on a singular gw_port_id retrieved from a router. We need to have a context that clearly identifies a gateway instance we are working with.

Some thoughts on directions that could be taken:

1) Relying on the external_gateway_info dict order in the request body:

* may work for updates but seems brittle/difficult to maintain;
* does not help when in for the "delete" API.

2) Add an extra ID for each instance of external gateway info (treat it as an entity).

3) Make the extra gateway API more port-centric by allowing gateway port ID to be specified in an update or delete request so that there is no ambiguity.

To be revisited since since a choice actually needs to be made here.

Usability for an operator is a concern but I also do not want to clutter the extra routes API.
Done

I can extend this paragraph to say it - I think it's a useful thing to note.

I think Neutron would need to get modelling for the "administrative distance" (or sometimes "preference") concept to resolve tie-breakers when it comes to routes to the same next-hop that come from different sources.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Administrative_distance

I've seen different modes implemented where:

* The lowest administrative distance assigned to the protocol by the system determines which route to the same destination wins;
* "Inter-protocol ECMP" - when load-sharing is done across routes that come from different sources (static, different dynamic routing protocols) provided they have the same destination and metric.

So, there's a bit more modelling to do from what I guess.

Perhaps easier to understand: "ECMP routes can result in black-holing of traffic if the next hop of a route becomes unreachable"

Note that there is a bug related to default routes not being added to OVN NB if a segment_id of a subnet is not set to `None`:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/2003842

This bug needs to be fixed to properly support the multiple gateways on a multi-segment network case but it affects Neutron as it is even without this feature.

Discussed that further with Rodolfo

https://meetings.opendev.org/irclogs/%23openstack-neutron/%23openstack-neutron.2023-01-27.log.html#t2023-01-27T14:30:42

and the case where a gateway is created on a multi-segment network will not be supported.

However, having gateways on different single-segment networks raises a different question: subnets on those networks may potentially overlap unless they have subnets allocated from the same subnet pool (i.e. they are in the same address scope).

Overlapping subnets lead to a situation where a next hop of a default route is reachable via directly connected routes added for either of the gateways and can inadvertently create a black hole (on a different segment that next-hop IP might not be a router or may not be assigned but we'd still get a logical flow for it). BFD would limit the impact of that to a degree. We could also get into a situation where next hops themselves would match in which case there would be a conflict during a route addition (while routes have a matching 0.0.0.0/0 destination and next-hop they have a different address scope/VRF).

I am going to explore how to guard an operator against that.

nova/tests/fixtures/libvirt.py.message: A comment explaining why this is good enough (there must be a reason why real libvirt has different APIs, right?) would be helpful

I think this was done as a quick shortcut.  As you don't want to re-implement the whole of CPU comparison/baseline calculation.  But I agree, we (I?) need to come up with definitely come up with more than calling the older APIs.

FWIW, I've documented here[1] the reasons for different APIs are documented here: One of the main things that the newer APIs take more parameters into consideration.  E.g.


    +-----------+--------------------+-----------------------------+
    |           | compareCPU()       | compareHypervisorCPU()      |
    +-----------+--------------------+-----------------------------+
    |           | XML describing the | XML describing the CPU      |
    |           | CPU to be compared | to be compared              |
    |           +--------------------+-----------------------------+
    |           |                    | path to the QEMU binary     |
    |           |                    +-----------------------------+
    |Parameters |                    | the type of virtualization  |
    |           |                    | (e.g. KVM, QEMU)            |
    |           |                    +-----------------------------+
    |           |                    | guest machine type          |
    |           |                    +-----------------------------+
    |           |                    | CPU architecture            |
    +-----------+--------------------+-----------------------------+


[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/xena/approved/cpu-selection-with-hypervisor-consideration.html#proposed-change

build-tools/build-docker-images/tag-mana.message: Could you describe why there is a notificationservice-base and notificationservice-base-v2?

Hi Mitch, thanks for catching this. We have added a notificationservice-base-v2 because ptp-notification needs to support both the legacy (v1) api and the recently added ORAN api (v2).

In order to do this, there is a container image for each api version and the user can choose to deploy either of them, or both.

So:
notificationservice-base = v1 api
notificationservice-base-v2 = v2 api

/COMMIT_MSG.message: What does 'work' relate to? Do we need it? Could we just say 'block storage cleanup', or split this into 'volume cleanup' and 'volume snapshot cleanup' commands?

Gotcha. In that case, I'd probably drop the work big and just stick with 'block storage cleanup'. The use of workers is an implementation detail that we don't need to expose to the end-user IMO. It'd be different if you could create/delete a generic "worker" resource but you can't

It relates to the concept of workers we have in cinder. For a resource (volume/snapshot) operation, we create a DB record in the workers table that allows us to track the status of the resource operation and also helps clean up the resource in case of failure with the help of this API.
Definitely we don't want to split this up into two commands since the only difference will be a parameter value for which we will be introducing a lot of redundant code.

Regarding the command name, I don't have a strong opinion here, honestly i just referenced the cinderclient command for this and it made sense because of the concept of workers on the API side. but I don't want to take decisions on behalf of cinder team since it would be difficult to change the command later. I will ask cinder team to provide feedback on this as well.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/puppet/keyst.message: how does this get applied to non-subcloud based on https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/stx-puppet/+/870803/2/puppet-manifests/src/modules/openstack/manifests/keystone.pp#39 which scopes to subcloud?
Please confirm that 'keystone::cache::enabled' is "False" by default (so that caching is disabled for subcloud.

Hi Andy, From keystone documentation: "Each subsystem is configured to cache by default. However, the global toggle for caching defaults to False. A subsystem is only able to cache responses if the global toggle is enabled."
Also the backend option is set by default to dogpile.cache.null. From Keystone documentation: dogpile.cache.null - A “null” backend that effectively disables all cache operations.(Default).

hi John, thanks for raising this doubt. Based on above review that it would be scoped to subcloud and primary region (region_config == false), which covers central cloud and standalone systems. It would apply keystone:cache on all nodes with keystone enabled, but in this config code, cache would be disabled for subclouds.

Can you also change the blueprint link direclty to:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/mistral/+spec/distribute-mistral-operations

Hello, that's a great and pretty big change.
IIUC, you are going to change some others things to start through RPC (not only tasks)?
Can you describe a little bit more what is the motivation behind this, what was the original problem?
It may be done by adding more info on the blueprint

As a part of blueprint distribute-mistral-operations, we have added changes to run task with RPC. Tasks will be created in IDLE state and RPC request will be created to run tasks.
In test_task_type UT, we are using nested workflow where first task is responsible to start inner workflow, due to above changes first task is created in IDLE state so, we should wait till execution success to assert all the types of tasks getting created for the workbook.

Link to fix for failing Test case review: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/mistral-tempest-plugin/+/869652
